Posts.Content: Hi Judith  First of all congratulations on finishing your treatment. I agree with you when you say that you wonder he you find the strength to go through the treatment when it is so overwhelming at the beginning but as you said anybody who comes through this journey is special, very special indeed. I was diagnosed in July 2011 at 32 years old and in three years my life has changed beyond recognition: after lumpectomy, ANC, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and Herceptin my biggest blessing was to become a mother in June 2013 and my precious little boy is prof that we can surpass all the challenges that cancer throw at you and still find true happiness and joy in life amid so many challenges. There is life after cancer we just need to keep on fighting. Love Susy
Posts.Title: Finished treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Son, Didn't know that. How does that work? My dentist does private and also NHS treatments.
Posts.Title: Medical Exemption Certificate

Posts.Content: Hi Son, Ok I will try because there are certain treatments that I have done with them through the NHS like removing teeth but when is for fillings I have gone through private so I will see as I am due for a check up. Will also check for eye test as well for contact lenses as I use them and have a direct debit for them.  Any cost that this cover is welcome - only positive thing from BC. Thanks Susy xxx
Posts.Title: Medical Exemption Certificate

Posts.Content: Hi, I am so sorry that you are going through this journey a second time but you got through it once you will get through it again and come on top!!!! I have a porthacath and it is a godsend!!!!! No more looking for dodgy veins and you won't feel a thing when chemo is being given. I had it inserted with a local anesthetic and sedation last November. Had to be careful the first week, no brisk movements, stiff neck  and was a bit sore, but after that no pain. It is worth it, for me it was and still have been as I am having herceptin. Take care  Susy
Posts.Title: New to Macmillan Support

Posts.Content: SaxxyD Your hubby did the same as my husband. When he got a new adaptor he was so excited about how many different ways and places he could use it that he said: "This adaptor is so good that you can even used it to blow dry your hair when we go on holidays!" and this was a few days after he shaved my hair and the remaining hair had fallen out. His face said it all, he was so embarrased that he did not know what to say!!! I suggested him to use it to blow dry his chest hair which made us laugh until we cried.LOL
Posts.Title: A post chemo smile!

Posts.Content: Hi Mary, I had such a laugh with your post, hubbies come out with the strangest yet funny things that only us will laugh at!!! My hubby used to caress my bald head all the time and in a strange way I kinda miss it now that my hair is around 2/3 inches long. He used to tell them me that I still looked beautiful eventough I had no hair. Keep up with the homour, it certainly helps to get through the darkest hours in this journey... xxx Susy
Posts.Title: A post chemo smile!

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne, I think you should to your BCN or other oncologist at your hospital about the fertility aspect. I was diagnosed last July at 32 years old and not only her but my oncologist spoke to me about conserving my eggs eventhough at the time I didn't think about it. I was so shocked that I am glad that they mentioned it and I was referred to a fertility specialist. As my onc knew that I was married with no children, that was her priority after my op. She was happy to delay my treatment for a couple of months so the eggs could be collected. I was supposed to have 3 FEC and 3 other that  I can't remember the name but because my white blood cells were getting lower and lower each time and the latter 3 the effects on fertility are not known and its even worse for the white blood cells, my onc gave us the option of deciding if we wanted to go ahead with the initial treatment or change it for FEC only, so I decided of having just FEC and had 5 cycles instead of 6, as with 5 I had the dose that I was supposed to have anyway.  In my family there are no cases of breast cancer, apart from me and my older sister that was diagnosed even younger than me at 28, so my onc is going to refer me for a genetic study to see if I have mutations on the BRCA1 or BRCA2. Press on it as it is very important to you and because your fertility is being put at risk because of cancer you can have the fertility treatment or even an initial discussion on the NHS and they are very quick to make appointments. I had mine 1 week after speaking to my onc. All the best Susy
Posts.Title: Anyone else been given the following 2 chemos???

Posts.Content: Hi Senga, For me radiotherapy was fine, only felt tired twice and one day under the weather but appart from that it was fine. In the hospital the radiologist (i think this is was they are called) will give aqueous cream that I put twice a day or when I felt I needed more.On the weekend I used to put a thick layer of the cream and let it stay until as long as I could until I had a shower to keep the skin really moisturised. It really helped. Well my breast looked like it had gone on holiday and the rest of my body had stayed at home LOL. Finished radiotherapy 2 weeks ago, still is a bit dark but slowly peeling and new skin is cominh up, but it does not hurt. Something that I think really helped was the exercises I was given to do after the operation and I made sure that I could move my arm as before the surgery, cause it tends to cause your joins to become stiff. All the best
Posts.Title: starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi I did use it and don't regret it, eventhough I lost my hair. I used it for 4 cycles but as it was thinning decided not to use it for the remaining. I don't regret it because it allowed me to loose my hair at a slower pace - my personal choice - but I know that some people don't like the fact that you are loosing it slowly, they prefer to loose it straight away. It was nor stressful for me to loose it this way as it allowed me slowly to get used to the idea that eventually I would go bald. My hair was very long and curly and I cut it shoulder lenght after the 2nd as I was getting some bald patches and with shorter hair people did not notice the baldness. Then after my 3rd, cut it shorter and then after the 5th I had it shaved, which I cry but got used to it.  Everybody has different opinions regarding the use of cold cap and I think you should do what is comfortable and what feels right for you.  All the best with your decision.
Posts.Title: A Cold cap - did it work for you?

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, Whatever helps us to go through this situation should be respected and celebrated just for the fact that its helping us to go through what we are going through. All of us have the right to express ourselves but in a manner that will not offend people "around" us. I wish all the best to everyone, no matter what they belief. Susy
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Hi Carole, The cold cap has a 50/50 chance of working. I was in the 50% that didn't. However, I don't regret using it. I managed to keep most of my hair just before my 5th cycle. It started falling slowly just before my 2nd cycle but at least I kept my hair for most of the time. I cut it short twice and as my hair was curly, people didn't notice my patches, in reality people were saying how good I looked with my new haircut. Just before my last cycle, my hubby shaved my hair and it was tough but as I dealt with it slowly it wasn't a shock for me but I think it depends on how you deal with things. I think it was good for me as your body goes through so much that keeping your hair for longer helps you to feel more normal. I lost my body hair just before my 2nd and it was good not to have to shave LOL. After that I used headscarves and my two wigs - was lucky enough to get one like my normal hair and one short from my sister.  You have to stay for longer when having your chemo and you might have headaches because of it I only had it the first time and if you do have it take conditioner with you as I helps to draw out humidity from the folicles and also so your hair doesn't get stuck onto the cap. I finished my chemo at the end of Jan and my hair is growing now, looking forward to stop using wigs and headscarves now. Hope it helps, xxx Susy
Posts.Title: Cold Cap. Does it work?

Posts.Content: Glad to help :)  First time the nurses forgot to tell me to take conditioner and my hair was completely stuck to the cap as it froze!  I also took a hat or had a hoddie as my hair being curly looked like a mess, more of a hamster's bed !!!!!! I am making good progress, just went back to work -part-time for now - and really enjoying going back to normal and looking forward to the future. All the best for Monday xxxx P.S: If you suffer for constipation like me (it was awful) there are some natural chewable cubes really good. I was given Senna on my 2nd cycle in the hospital but it didn't work. Then on my 3rd cycle they gave me the syrup thing really sweet that I would have to take almost half of the bottle to have some bowl movement so I gave up. Then I discovered this cubes they are from Ortis an are called Fruits & Fibres and after my 3rd cycle I started take them on the 1st day of chemo and it was a relief!!!!!
Posts.Title: Cold Cap. Does it work?

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, We can get flu jab my onc wanted me to have one last year as I started chemo in October last year but at the time there was no jabs in stock in September. Glad you mentioned it will ask my onc next week as I have an appointment. Just thinking about the lovely "presents" children like to share with us at school and will defo get one..... Let you know next week Susy
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, Its so good the feeling of going back to work and I hope you can do it as soon it is possible to you. Like you I work in a school as a HLTA and went back last April after being away since September 2011. You look at your work with different eyes and approach it differently, eventhough you are still at the same job. The children are so good at putting a smile in your face and they notice the difference. For example, when I went back in April my hair was still very short and I decided to use hats and headscarves and made that part of my "new look". The children that I had work with the previous year were Y5 and one of them asked if I had converted to Islam - please take no offence about this whoever is reading - and I just said that I decided to change my style and look. Many of them came to me saying how much they have missed me and what had happened to me, all sort of questions as you can imagine. Returning in september I decided to let my hair out as it is about 2/3 inches long and curly and while I was telling off a child during playtime, she was staring at me and I thought to myself what is wrong with her. She looked into my eyes and really loud and stern she said:"Miss why did you cut your hair?" OMG for a few seconds I didn't know what to say as she was only 5 years old  when I left for my treatments and she still remember how I used to look. Just be really careful as your immune system will be a wreck. Never had a cold or infection while doing chemo and that lasted almost a year. As soon I went back had a throat infection where I lost my voice completely and first day the children were in last week caught a cold got better but this week got worse and I am still sneezing a lot and caughing. And that is being really careful using hand gel, my own pencils, pens and everything and I am only working 3 days a week. All the best Susy
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, We can get flu jab my onc wanted me to have one last year as I started chemo in October last year but at the time there was no jabs in stock in September. Glad you mentioned it will ask my onc next week as I have an appointment. Just thinking about the lovely "presents" children like to share with us at school and will defo get one..... Let you know next week Susy

Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Hi mistymoley Thanks for your reply.I'm thinking that it might be something along the lines of cording but not sure. Just wanted to know if anyone had same symptoms. Well have appointment with oncologist on Monday so will chat about it.
Posts.Title: "Vein Pulling" Sensation and Pain

Posts.Content: Hello ladies, I wonder if anyone can help me with the fillowing. I have finished my treatment in November 2012 - lumpectomy, chemo, rads and Herceptin. Everything has been fine until last December when out of the blue I started to feel some pain under my affected breast by the ribs like someone had punched me. After a week or so the pain disappeared. Then last month out came back and as it didn't get better I started to worry and when I looked in the mirror and I put my arm up I could see and feel 2 veins quite hard like when you have cording and it was painful to touch and just putting my arm up without touching was very painful. Got an appointment with GP a few days later and eventhough the pain got less and better my GP was puzzled as he has never seen anything like it. He said that he doesn't think is cancer related but sent me for a scan which will b at the end of this month. Had a mammogram last week which made the pain come back and will see oncologist which btw I'm dreading..... Has anyone experienced something similar? Thanks Susy
Posts.Title: "Vein Pulling" Sensation and Pain

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, I am almost half way of the Herceptin - next week is cycle 9 - and went back to work in April. I was off work since September 2011 and was working full-time. I had chemo from October to January, had radio mid February to mid March and started Herceptin at the end of March. When I went back it was agreed with my employer - I am a higher level teaching assistant - to go back on a staggered return, so I started working 3 days a week.  My energy levels are better than when I was having chemo, but they are nowhere closer to what they were before. As many of you here are TAs, you know that it is a very demanding job, phisically and mentally so I am struggling to keep up as my brain says that I can do it but my body is saying take it easy. Also in my school appearence is very important so we need to look the part, more like an office so need to look good and with my hair now about 2/3 inches it does help and also need to make sure that my pimples - reactio from the Herceptin - are well disguised. I find that with Herceptin I feel quite tired the day I have it and I need to sleep it off to get it out my system. By the time I am almost 100% here comes the next one. Also my immune system is still messed up from chemo, catching all the bugs from the children, the last 2 weeks have been really tough and winter is not here, don't want to think how it will be during that time. I was hoping of going on full-time in September but I am still doing 3 days a week. I am quite lucky as I am getting full-time pay instead of part-time so have no preassure of getting less money so normal stress levels on this departement. All I can say to you is to take it as it comes and don't push yourselves beyond you can. Susy
Posts.Title: FEC-T and Heceptin ??? What to expect?

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda & all, I know what you mean by saying that its a rollercoaster and that the hardest is to tell your family.... I am the second person in my family to be diagnosed with BC, the first was my sister at 27 years old. 5 year later, at 32 years old, I had to give the same news to my parents, worst day ever.... still remember it as it was yesterday. My husband has really looked after me and being so supportive but there is something that I keep thinking: how I am robbing him of being a father as we don't have children and we were planning it when we got the news of the BC. After having chemo (finished end of Jan) don't know how my fertility is and can't think of children in the next couple of years.   So, eventhough it was hard telling your children, you are blessed by having them in your life. Enjoy every precious moment you have with them and I am sure that you will have many years ahead of you to see them achieve their dreams. xxx Susy
Posts.Title: Scared!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tina, I am really sorry that you are having such a bad time with your chemo nurses, it really makes me feel angry  on your behalf as I have such wonderful nurses at my chemo suit - well there is one so and so but the rest make up for her. The nurse you mentioned  is really unprofessional, no sympathy what so ever and really stupid!!!!! What you are describing happened to me and when  I went for my 3rd chemo as my arm was a bit swollen and painful the nurses refused to give me chemo and I was referred to have a porth-a-cath inserted and that was the best thing that had happened during this whole thing.  It took a good 2 months for my arm to kinda come back to normal and at the moment my wedding ring still doesn't fit but at least my arm is not in pain and this arm is the one that had to do everything relating to carrying bags and lift things.  Hope you are better now Susy
Posts.Title: Sore arm/vein pain

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy I was 32 when I was diagnosed and eventhough I easily married I did not want to wait for the fertility treatment so I had chemo after lumpectomy and ANC. My husband agreed also with that as it was a joint decision and it as one the hardest decisions we had to make as just before I was diagnosed we r planningon startinga family. I resigned myself to b just the 2 of us. Then when I was half way through herceptin found out I was pregnant. We were very anxious as we did not know if the treatment would've  affected our unborn baby but my oncologist was very supportive. She said that as I was offered the possibility of having herceptin for 6 months  but had chosen to have 12 months in reality I had almost 8 months so stopping it would not make much of a difference. Our miracle baby is now 15 months old and he developing really well. Hope my story gives u some hope if u decide not to have the fertility treatment. BTW my older sister also had BC  and she did not have fertility treatment and she has a 20 month boy and shes pregnant with a baby girl who will arrive by the end of November Susy
Posts.Title: Freezing eggs or embryos

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Haven't posted for a long time but hav been reading the posts and I had to add something. Apart from the obvious that most of us hear, the worst I heard was from my boss and to think that he is a headmaster what influence he's having in young minds it actually scares me. After returning to work being away for 9 months during the majority of my treatment I was wearing head scarves and he found it hard to see me with my head covered. After 6 weeks of of holidays went back with my short hair. He was amazed and his compliment was "well I'm sure you are cancer free because you hair is growing. If you still had cancer you hair would not grow". Needless to say I was in shock with his ignorance and refused to reason with someone like him. Also during chemo went for the regular blood tests and had priority over everybody that was waiting to have the blood tests done and a man in his 60s starting complaining that a young person like me could not wait like everybody else - was 32 at the time - and started a scene in a pretty busy rroom well I said to him that I wouldn't mind swapping with him as I had cancer and he probably had something that could wait. He did not say a word.
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, I also suffered from really bad constipation and tried everything but the only thing that worked was   natural chewable cubes from Ortis  called Fruits & Fibres and after my 3rd cycle I started take them on the 1st day of chemo and it was a relief!!!!! You can take half of one but I had one whole and it did the trick. Good recovery  Susy xxx
Posts.Title: neutropenia

Posts.Content: Hi Irene, I also was neutropenic throughout my chemo but not as bad as you and never had to stay in hospital. During those days I was really careful with what I ate and it helped. I had plenty of the following every day and never missed a treatment: beetroot fresh greens carrots papaya tomatoes brussels sprouts watercress spinach broccoli red, yellow pepers butternut squash fish I bought a fruit juicer so I could juice carrot with beetroot, papaya, and other fruits. At the end I had to force myself to have beetroot I got sick of it but it really helped. So any fruit or vegetable that is yellow, red or dark green is good to raise white blood cells. Hope it helps and good recovery Susy xxx
Posts.Title: neutropenia
